item.title: What We Owe To Each Other
item.description:
The topic of changing verbiage within the tech industry, particularly as it relates to references to “master,” particularly in the “master/slave” contexts, but also in places like “master” branch in git (which does, in fact, have its roots in the “master/slave” paradigm), came up in a couple of Slack groups in which I participate.

It’s certainly not new (some discussions on the matter date back a decade or more), but it’s always kind of a contentious topic when it comes up, despite the terminology getting phased out over time.

item.title: A Riot Is the Language of the Unheard
item.description:
So I attended a protest the other day. It was the first time I’d been downtown since it started and I had walked there (and back) from one of the suburbs. A nearly 5 mile walk each way, with the inner-most mile or two containing a lot of plywood covering up a lot of damage.

But you know what stuck out to me? Two things:

  1. Which places were hit.
  2. Of the places that were damaged and thus boarded up, which had murals and which had graffiti.

These two things speak volumes about the situation.
